abstract_problem: An operations team must launch {num_tasks} independent work orders on one shared facility over a discrete calendar. The facility can provide at most {resource_capacity} units of capacity at any time tick, and each order continuously consumes a fixed amount of that capacity while it is being processed. Each order requires a fixed number of consecutive ticks; once it begins it must proceed without pausing. Every order becomes ready at its own ready time and must be launched no later than its last allowed start time. In addition, each order has a preferred (target) launch tick; starting later than that target creates a service delay. The delay for an order is the amount of time its chosen start tick exceeds its target (and is zero if it starts on or before the target). The plan must choose exactly one start tick for each order within its allowed window, while never exceeding shared capacity at any tick, and minimize the sum of delays across all orders. The calendar spans ticks {min_time} through {max_time}, covering {horizon} ticks in total.

tasks.description:
Job-level data. Each row corresponds to one job. The columns describe how long the job runs, how much shared facility capacity it consumes while running, when it becomes eligible to start, the last time it is still allowed to start, and the preferred (target) start tick used to measure service delay. The allowed start window is defined by `release_time` and `latest_start`; start ticks outside this window are not permitted.
Data format:
| task_id | duration | resource_demand | release_time | latest_start | target_start |
|--------|----------|-----------------|--------------|--------------|--------------|
| <int>  | <int>    | <int>           | <int>        | <int>        | <int>        |

parameters.description:
Global scenario settings. Each row defines a single scalar setting that applies to the whole instance, such as the number of jobs, the machine's total capacity, and the bounds of the discrete timeline used to evaluate capacity usage.
Data format:
| parameter | value |
|----------|-------|
| <string> | <string_or_number> |
